description: From Middle English wagelen (attested in wagelyng), possibly a borrowing of Middle Low German wagelen; equivalent to wag +‎ -le (“(frequentative)”). Compare continental equivalents Middle High German wacken ( > Danish vakle, German wackeln), Swedish vagla, West Frisian waggelje, Low German wackeln, Dutch waggelen.

examples: Give the cable a waggle to let it come out quicker.

entries.meaning: (golf) The preliminary swinging of the club head back and forth over the ball in the line of the proposed stroke.

verbs.description: waggle (third-person singular simple present waggles, present participle waggling, simple past and past participle waggled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move (something) with short, quick motions; to wobble.
(intransitive) To reel, sway, or move from side to side; to move with a wagging motion; to waddle.
